bibl.title: Petitioner v. Defendant. Type of Document.
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image.

keywords.term: Pierce, John A. Speck, Robert D. Baldwin, Harris Hanford, C. H. Aspland, Lise C. White, E. T. Pomeroy, Frances A. Aspland, Andrew Aspland, Ella May Brown, Abel Wilkinson, M. A. Aspland, John H. White, E. T. Aspland, Jennie Switzer, W. D. Magnus, Franz Sempee,John M. Sawyer, Mary Spence, William C. Corbett, J. E. Eldridge, John Hair, N. C. Valentine, John E. Backus, C. F. Donovan, G. J. Low, J. R. Thomas, C. Monroe, W. A. Fenton, James E. Prather, Leander H. Cisna, M. A. Dempsey, C. C. Willia, C. Thomas Gould, P. James, Thomas Doane, H. W. Roadnight, J. F. Lipschuetz, I. Valentine, J. E. Morgan, U. H. Hair, N. C. Van Ness, John Q. Gill, William Frazier, R. J. O'Brien, Lipschuetz, Isador Boyd, L. F. Hillard, Barry N. McNulty, Philip Byers, William Traut, A. Bishop, B. H. Cannon, H. L. Crowley, J. A. Frazier, R. J. Fenton, James, E. Pierce, John A. La Valley, William J. div1.p: IN THE SUPERIOR COURT OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON
IN AND FOR THE COUNTY OF SPOKANE.
In the Matter of the appli- cation of George Webster, for
A Writ of Error Coram Nobis

I, L. F. Boyd, being duly sworn say; that I am now and have been ever since the 21st day of May, A. D. 1896, the duly elected, qualified and acting Clerk of the City of Spokane, Washington. That as such Clerk I am the legal custodian of the Election Register of Cannon Precinct in the Third Ward in and for the said City, of the qualified electors for the City Election held in Spokane, Washington, on the 4th day of May , A. D. 1897, and of the Poll Book of the said City Election held on the 4th day of May , A.D. 1897, in the said Can- non Precinct in the Third Wards of said City. That said books are now in my office and in my custody. That in said Election Register of qualified electors of said Cannon Precinct in said Third Ward of said City, the following entry concerning one Isidor Lipschuetz app pears of record, to-wit:-

" Registration Book, City of Spokane, Cannon Precinct, Third Ward, Number Registered Votes 225, Registered Poll List, Cannon Pre- cinct, City of Spokane, Washington, for the year 1897, date of reg- istration April 8th, 1897, name, Isidor Lipschuetz, age 41 years, oc- cupation, Barber, Place of residence #1204 Fourth Avenue, Place of birth, Germany, Time of residence in State 7 years, in County 7 ears, in ward 7 months. Time and place of declaration of intention of naturalization, Philadelphia, Pa. Date of Intention of naturalization, A. D. 1876, Signature, Isador Lipschuetz."

That the said Poll Book for said City Election held on the 4th day of May, A.D.1897, in said City and Ptecinct, in the Third Ward in the City of Spokane, State of Washington, the following entry concern ing one Isidor Lipschuetz appears of Record, to-wit:-

"Poll Book of elelction held in Cannon Precinct, City of Spo- kane of Washinto n, on the 4th day of May, A. D. 1897at which time A. Traut was inspector, J. H. Bishop and P. McNulty was Judges and H. L. Cannon and J. A. Crowley were Clerks, or said election, the following named person vating there, No .64, name of voter, Isidor Lipschuetz."

Affiant further says that the aforesaid Poll Book is duly at- tested by the Inspector, Judges, and Clerks of said City Election, and was the official return of said City Election to the City Counsil in and for the City of Spokane, Washington, acting as a Board of Can- vassers at said election, and affiant further deposes and sayd that at the time the said Isidor Lipschuetz registered on the said 8th day of April, A.D.1897, he and made subscribed the following oath, to- wit:--

I, Isidor Lipschuetz do solemly swear or affirm that I am a male person over twenty years, eleven months ,and ten days of age, that I am a naturalized citizen of the United States, that I have been an actual permanent resident of the State of Washington for eleven months and ten days last past, of the County of Spokane for seventy days last past, and of the Precinct ten days last past, and that I have not lost my civil rights by reason of being convicted of an infamous crime.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 8th day of April, 1897.
L. F. Boyd, City Clerk and ex- officio-Register.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 3rd day of January, a. D.1898.
Del Cary Smith N O T A R Y P U B L I C for Washington, residing at Spokane, Washington.
IN THE SUPERIOR COURT OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON
IN AND FOR THE COUNTY OF SPOKANE.
In the Matter of the application of George Webster, for
A Writ of Error Coram Nobis

I, R. J. Frazier being duly sworn say; That I am one of the jurors who tried the above named petitioner, relator and defendant. That I am acquainted with Isidor Lipschuetz who was also one of the jurors who tried the said petitioner, relator and defendant above named. That I was present in the Court Room durinng the timw the said Isidor Lipschuetz was being examined, touching his qualifications to act and serve as a juror in said cause. And that in answer to the questions propounded to the said Isidor Lipschuetz as to his length of residence in Spokane County, he the said juror answered that he had resided in said City of Spokane for about eight years, and in answer to the following question; "Do you know anything that would prevent you from being a fair and impartial juror?" he the said juror Isidor Lipschuetz answered "Not to my knowledge." And in answe to the following question, "Have you no such an opinion as to require evidence to change that opinion?" the said juror answ ered, "No, sir." Whereas in truth and in fact the said Isidor Lips- chuetz while the jury were deliberating on the verdict of said cause, stated to this affiant that he the said Isidor Lipschuetz was in pos- session of facts within his own knowledge, and facts that have not been testified by any of the witnesses on trial of said cause that convinced him the said Isidor Lipschuetz beyond a reasonable doubt that the sad petitioner, relator and defendant above named was guilty of the crime of murder and that he should be hanged for such offense. And affiant further deposes and says, that the said juror Isidor Lipschuetz during the deliberation of the jury, became and was extremely bitter and malicious in his conduct toward said peti- tionerm relator and defendant above named, and told this affiant that he said Isidor Lipschuetz, had made up his mind that the said George Webster was guilty of said offense before any testimony in the cause had been offered, and repeatedly said to the affiant in the jury room "I would like to see Webster taken out of the jail right now and hung without any further trial or delay of any kind".
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 30th day of December, 1897.
Del Cary Smith N O T A R Y P U B L I C for Washington, residing at Spokane, Washington.
IN THE SUPERIOR COURT OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON
IN AND FOR THE COUNTY OF SPOKANE.
In the Matter of the application of George Webster, for
A Writ of Error Coram Nobis

I, James E. Fenton, being duly sworn say that I am one of the attorneys for the above named petitioner, relator and defendant, George Webster. That on the 3rd day of November, A.D. 1896, the fol- lowing provision of the Constitution of the State of Idaho, was in force and effect touching the qualifications of the electors.

Section 2. Except as in this Article otherwise provided, every male citizen of the United States, twenty-one years old, who has actually resided in this State of Territory, for six months and in the County where he offers to vote, 30 days next preceeding the day of election, is registered as provided by law is a qualified elector; and until otherwise provided by the Leg- islature, who have the qualifications prescribed in this Ar- ticle, may continue to hold such school office and vote at such school elections, as provided by the laws of Idaho Territory."

That the said Constitution of the State of Idaho, which the said Sec. 2, of Art. 6 was a part, was adopted on the 6th day of August, A. D. 1899 and the same is now and has ever since said date been in full force and effect and has not been amended.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 3rd day of January, 1898.
Del Cary Smith N O T A R Y P U B L I C for Washington, residing at Spokane, Washington.

I, Del Cary Smith being duly sworn say; that I am one of the attorneys for the above and goregoing named petitioner, re- lator and defendant named in the foregoing application and af- fidavits for a Writ of Error Coram Nobis.

That on the 3rd day of January, A. D. L89 , at the hour of 3-30 o'clock P. M. I personally served upon John A. Pierce, Prosecuting Attorney in and for Spokane County, State of Washington, full true and correct copies of the foregoing application of George Webster for a Writ of Error Coram Nobis, and the affidavits thereto attached, by personally delivering to said John A. Pierce on said date, said full true and correct copies.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 3rd day of January, 1898.
W. M. Byers N O T A R Y P U B L I C for Washington, residing at Spokane, Washington.
No. 771. Filed January 3rd, 1898. at 4-30 P. M. J. R. Low, Clerk. C. J. Donovan,
IN THE SUPERIOR COURT OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON
IN AND FOR THE COUNTY OF SPOKANE.
In the Matter of the application of George Webster, for
A Writ of Error Coram Nobis

I, William J. La Balley being duly sworn depose and say, that I am a citizen of the United States and a resident of Spokane, Wash- ington and over the age of twenty-one years. That I am acquainted with Isidor Lipschuetz, who is a barger engaged in business at 515 Main Avenue in the City of Spokane, Washington, and have been ac- quaited with the said Isidor Lipschuetz ever since the 4th day of November A. D. 1896. That I resided in the City of Wallace, State of Idaho from the 4th day of November, A. D. 1896 until the 27th dat of December, A.D. 1896, continuously. That the said Isidor Lipschuet who is now engaged in the barber business at 515 Main Avenue Spokane, Washington, resided in the City of Wallace, State of Idaho, contin- uously from the 4th day of November, A.D.1896, until the 27th day of December, A.D.1896, and that I saw the said Isidor Lipschuetz almost daily between the said 4th day of November, A.D. 1896 and the 27th day of December, A.D.1896, at the City of Wallace? State of Idaho, and he the said Isidor Lipschuetz was engaged in the barber business at the City of Wallace during said time. That the said Isidor Lips- chuetz who resided in the City of Wallace, State of Idaho from said 4th day of November, A.D.1896 until the 27th day of December, A.D. 1896 is the same Isidor Lipschuetz who served upob the jury in the above entitled case of the Stateof Washigton -vs- George Webster and the same person who is now engaged in the barber business at No. 515 Main Avenue Spokane, Washington. That the said Isidor Lipschuetz had not been an inhabitant of Spokane County, Washigton for the period of oe year next preceeding the 14th day of September, A.D.1897.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 8th day of January, 1898.
Del Cary Smith N O T A R Y P U B L I C for Washington, residing at Spokane, Washington.
IN THE SUPERIOR COURT OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON
IN AND FOR THE COUNTY OF SPOKANE.
In the Matter of the application of George Webster, for
A Writ of Error Coram Nobis

I, William Semper being duly swoen say; shat I am a citizen of the United States and a resident of Spokane, Washington, and over the age of twenty-one years. That I am acquainted with Isidor Lips- schuetz, a barber now engaged in business at 515 Main Avenue Av- enue in the City of Spokane, Washington. That I have been acquainted with him the said Isidor Lipschuetz ever since the 1st day of March A.D.1895. That the said Isidor Lipschuetz ever since the 1st day of March A.D.1895. That the said Isidor Lipschuetz who us now engaged in the barber business at 515 Main Avenue, Spokane, Washington, resided con- tinuously in the State of Idaho for more than one year and a half im- mediately preceeding the 7th day of October, A.D.1896 and was enfafed in the barber business in the State of Idaho for the greater portion of said time. That the said Isidor Lipschuetz who resided in the State of Idaho during said time is the same Isidor Lipschuetz who is now engaged in business at 515 Main Avenue in said City of Spo- kane, Washington. That said Isidor Lipschuetz had not been a resi- dent of the City of Spokane, Washington, durng one yaer preceeding the 14th day of September, A.D. 1897 and was not an elector of the said State of Washington on the said 14th day of September, A.D. 1897.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 8th day of January, A.D. 1898.
Notary Public for Washington, residing at Spokane, Washington.
IN THE SUPERIOR COURT OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON
IN AND FOR THE COUNTY OF SPOKANE.
In the Matter of the application of George Webster, for
A Writ of Error Coram Nobis

I, James Flynn, being duly sworn say; that I am a citizen of the United States, now residing at Spokane, Washington, and over twenty-one years of age. That I am acquained with Isidor Lipschuet a barber now engaged in business at No. 515 Main Avenue Spokane, Washington, and that I have been acquainted with the said Isidor Lips- schuetz ever since the first day of NovemberA.D. 1894. That the said Isidor Lipschuetz, who is now engaged in business at No. 515 Main Avenue Spokane, Washington, resided in the State of Idaho for two immediately prior to November 1s6, A.D. 1896, and was engaged in the barber business for a greater portion of the time mentioned. That the said Isidor Lipschuetz who resided in the State of Idaho, during the said two years prior to November 11st, 1896, is the same Isidor Lipschuetz who is now engaged in business as a barber at No. 515 Main Avenue Spokane, Washington, and is the same Isidor Lips- schuetz who was one of the trial jurors in the above entitled case of the State of Washington -vs- George Webster, and that said Isidor Lipschuetz had not been a resident of the City of Spokane, Spokane County, State of Washington, for one year prior to the 14th day of September, A.D.1897 and was not an elector of the State of Washington on said 14th day of September A.D.1897.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 8th day of January, A.D. 1989.
Notary Public for Washington, residing at Spokane, Washington.
IN THE SUPERIOR COURT OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON
IN AND FOR THE COUNTY OF SPOKANE.
In the Matter of the application of George Webster, for
A Writ of Error Coram Nobis

I, Harry Swift being duly sworn say; that I am a citizen of the State of Idaho, and that I am over twenty-one years of age. That I am acquainted with Isidor Lipschuetz, a barber now engaged in business at 515 Main Avenue, Spokane, Washington. That I have been acquainted with said Isidor Lipschuetz ever since the 1st day of Oc- tober, A.D.1895. That said Isidor Lipschuetz, who is now engaged in business at No. 515 Main Avenue, Spokane, Washington, resided contin uously in the City of Wallace, State of Idaho from the 1st day of October, A.D.1895 until the 20th day of June, A.D.1896, at which time said affiant left the City of Wallace temporarily. That from said 1st day of October, A.D.1895 until 20th day of June, A.D. 1896, said Isidor Lipschuetz was engaged in the barber business at said City of Wallace, Idaho. That said Isidor Lipschuetz who resided in said City of Wallace during said time, to-wit:- from October 1st, 1895 until June 20th, A.D. 1896, is the same Isidor Lipschuetz who is now engaged in business at No. 515 Main Avenue in Spokane, Washington, and is the same Isidor Lipschuetz who sat upon the jury in the trial of the above case of the State of Wash ington -v-George Webster in September, A.D.1897.
Subscribed and sworn to before me this 8th day of January, A.D. 1898.
Notary Public for Washington, residing at Spokane, Washington.

11 1/2 A. That thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in the said case in the said Superior Court, that the said Petition for a Writ of Error Coram Nobis came on regularly for hearing before Hon. L. H. Prather, as Judge of the said Superior Court; upon the demurrer of the State of Washington thereto, which said demurrer is in writing, the words and figures as following, to-wit:-
IN THE SUPERIOR COURT OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON
IN AND FOR THE COUNTY OF SPOKANE.
In the Matter of the application of George Webster, for
A Writ of Error Coram Nobis
In the Matter of the application of George Webster, for A Writ of Error Coram Nobis
Comes now the State of Washington and demurs to the affidavit, petition and application of George Webster, affiant and petitioner herein, and for cause of dermurrer avers,
That the said affidavit, petition and application do not state facts sufficient to justify or sustain any further proceedings herein
WHEREFORE, The State of Washington prays that said affidavit, petition and application be now dismissed.

That upon the argument of said demurrer the same was sus- tained and thereupon the said petition of George Webster for a Writ of Error Coram Nobis was dismissed. To which order sustaining said demurrer and dismissing said petition, the said petitioner than and there excepted, and an exception was allowed.

Twelfth- That thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in said cause, that the said petitioner herein George Webster appealed from the said judgement and sentence to the Supreme Court of the State of Washington, znd thereafter such proceedings were had taken in said cause in the said Supreme Court, of the State of Washington, that the said Supreme Court of the State of Washington, on the 18th day of April, A.D. 1899, made and rendered its decision affirming the said judgment and sentence of the said Superior Court.

Thirteenth- That thereafter such proceedi ngs were had and taken in said cause in said Supreme Court, that the said petitioner George Webster did on the 18th day of May, A.D.1899, and within the time prescribed by the rules of the said Supreme Court and the laws of the State of Washington, filed a partition for a rehearing in the said Supreme Court, and thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in said Supreme Court, that the said petition for a re- taken in said Supreme Court, that the said petition for a re- hearing was, on the 7th day of June, A.D. 1899, denied.

Fourteenth- That thereafter such proceedings were hadand taken in said cause in the Superior Court, that the Hon. Leander H. Prath er, as Judge of the said Superior Court, did on the day of A.D.1899, make an order fixing Friday, the 28th day of July, A.D.1899, at the Spokane Counrt Jail in Spokane,Washington f or the execution of the said petitioner, and as the time and place for carrying into effect the said judgment and sentence and place for carrying into effect the said judgment and sentence and did, at said time, issue a death warrant commanding and directing the sheriff for Spokane County, Washington, to execute and hang the said petitioner on the 28th day of July, A.D.1899, which said order and death warrant is in writing in words and figures as follows, to- wit;
IN THE SUPERIOR COURT OF THE STATE OF WASHINGTON
IN AND FOR THE COUNTY OF SPOKANE.
W A R R A N T .
To R. D. Speck, sheriff of Spokane County, State of Wash- ington, GREETING:

W H E R E A S, as a day of the Superior Court of Spokane County, before the Honorable Leander H. Prather, judge of the said court, begun and held at the City of Spokane in the said county of Spokane, on the 13th day of May, 1897, in open court and in due form of law, the prosecuting attorney for Spokane County, State of Washington, presented again the said defendant, George Webster, an informaation charging him with the crime of murder in the first de gree in that he, the said defendant George Webster, in said county, and state on to-wit, the 6th day of May, 1897, then and there un- lawfully, feloniously and purposely and of his deliberate and pre- meditated malice, did kill Lise C. Aspland with a gun commonly called a revolver which he, the said George Webster, then and there held in hi s hand, and

WHEREAS, this case came on regularly for hearing in the Super- ior Court of the State of Washington in and for the county of Spo- kane, on the 13th day of May, 1897, the said court being in session and the said defendant bei ng present in person in open court and represented by his attorneys Messrs J. E. Fenton and Del Cary Smith and the state of Washington being represented by the prosecuting attorney for the said Spokane County;

Thereupon the said defendant George Webster, in open court and dult arraigned under said infor ation and asled to plead thereto and thereupon the said defendan, George Webster, pleaded not guilty to the crime in said information charged. And

WHEREAS, on the 17th day of September, 1897, in due course of law, a jury of twelve good and lawful men, to-wit: C. Thomas, William P. Gould, Thomas James, H. W. Doane, J. F. Roadnight, I, Lipschuetz, J. E. Valentine, U. H. Morgan, N. C. Hair, John Q. Van Ness, William Gill, and N. J. Frasier were drawn from the body of said Spokane County, and were duly selected, accepted and impanell- ed and swoen to well and truly try and true deliverance make of their verdict in the case of the State of Washington plain- tiff, and George Webster, defendant, according to the evidence and the instructions of the court, and

WHEREAS, after hearing the evidence in said case and the argu- ment of counsel and after hearing and receiving the instructions of the court, the said jury did retire in charge of sworn officers to deliberate on their verdict in said cause, and thereafter and on, to-wit, the 25th day of September, 1897, the said jury did return and render into open court, the said defendant George Webster being then and there personally present in open court, with his said at- torneys, the following verdict, to-wit:
We, the jury in the case of the Stateof Washington, plaintiff vs. George Webster defendant, find the defendant, George Webster, guilty as charged in the information.

Whereas, thereafter and on to-wit, the 27th day of September, 1897, the said defendant George Webster by his said attorneys gave and filed in said court notice of motion for a new trial herein and motion form a new trial herein, and on the 15th day of November, 1897, the said defendant George Webster being then and there per- sonally present with his said attorneys in open court, the said mo- tion for a new trial was overruled by the said court and thereafter to-wit, on the 15th day of November, 1897, with his said attorneys being personally present in open court, the said defendat George Webster by his said attorneys filed a motion for arrest of judgment herein and the said defendant on the 15th day of November, 1897, with his said attorneys being personally present in open court the said motion in arrest of judgment was overruled by the said court; and,

WHEREAS, the said court did on the 15th day of Noveber, 1897 fix the 16th day of November, 1897, as the day on which the said court would make, render and enter judgment and sentence upon said verdict, and

WHEREAS, on the 16th day of November, 1897, the said court be- ing in session and the said defendant George Webster being personal- ly present with his said attorneys Del Cary Smith in open court and the said court informedthe said defendant George Webster of the said verdict of the said jury, and then and there asked the said defend- ant George Webster if he the said defendan t, had any cause to show why the said court should not pronounce, make and render and enter judgment and sentence of the said courtupon the said verdict and there being no cause shown by or on behalf of the said defendant George Webster, the said court did then and there pronounce, make render and enter upon the said verdict the following judgment and sentence, to-wit;

"Upon the verdict of the jury in this cause finding you the said defendant, George Webster, guilty of murder in the first de- gree for the killing of Lise C. Aspland, the judgment of this court is that you are guilty of the crime of murder in the first degree:

Therefore, the judgment and sentence of this court is that you the said defendant, George Webster, be taken hence by the sheriff of said county to the jail of the said county and there safely and securely kept until a day and time certain to be fixed in the warrant for your execution, and that upon said day, between the hours of 6 o'clock and 10 o'clock in the forenoon of said day so to be fixed, you be taken from said jail by the said sheriff to the place to be by im selected and provided within the yard of the jaill of the said county in the said city of Spokane, county of Spokane, State of Washington and that you then and there by the said sheriff be hanged by the neck until you are dead."

WHEREAS, thereafter an appeal was taken by said defendant to the Supreme Court of the State of Washington, and at the May session A.D.1899, the Supreme court of the State of Washington begun and holden in Olympia, Washington, on the second Monday in May, A.D. 1899 it being the 8th day of the said month, among other the following was had; and done, to-wit: The following Judgment was rendered and duly entered of record:

"On Wednesday, June 7th, 1899, the case of the state of Washington, respondent, vs. George Webster, appellant, No. 3ii3, this cause having been heretofore submitted to the court upon the t transcript of the record of the Superior Court of Spokane County, and upon the argument of counsel, and the court having fully con- sidered te same and being duly advised in the premises and having filed its opinion in writing, it is now on this 7th day of June, A.D.1899, on motion of the prosecuting attorney of Spokane County, of counsel for respondent, considered, adjudged and decreed that the judgmet of the said Superior Court be and the same is hereby affirmed with costs, the petition for rehearing denied, and the said state of Washington have and recover of and from the said George Webster, the costs of this action taxed and allowed at sixty four and 20/100 dollars, and execution issue therefor.
And it is further ordered that said cause be remitted to the said Superior Court of Spokane County, Washington, for further proceeding in accordance with the opinion herein filed." And
WHEREAS, said remittitur from the said supreme court was duly received and filed in the sad Superior Court of Spokane County Washington, at 9.35 A.M. on the 20th day of June, 1899, and

WHEREAS, on the 15th day of June, 1899, the court did fix Saturday June 17th, 1899, as the day on which the said court would ddraw the death warrant int this case and deliver the same to the sheriff. And this being the said 17th day of June, 1899, and the defendanr George Webster being present in open court, with hs counsel J. E. Fenton, and Del Cary Smith,

NOW THEREFORE, it is by the court ordered and in the name of the State of Washington, you, R.D. Speck, sheriff of Spokane Couny Washington, are hereby commanded to take the said George Webster on the 28th day of July, 1899, between the hours of 6 o'clock and 10 o'clock in the forenoon of said day, to the said place of execution in the yard of the jail of the said Spokane County, and that you, George Webster, defendant, by the necknuntil he is dead, and that you the said R. R. Speck,sheriff aas aforesaid, make due execution and return of this warrant and your proceedings thereon as required by law.
Given under my hand and the seal of the said court this 17th day of June, A. D.1899.
Leander H. Prather Judge of the Superior Court of the state of Washington, in and for Spokane County.
(SEAL) Attest: James A. Drain Clerk of the Superior Court of the State of Washington in and for Spokane Co.

Fifteenth- That thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in the said cause, that the said petitioner did on the 14th day of July, A.D.1899, make and file with and presented to the Hon. John R. Rogers, Fovernor of the State of Washington, his petition for a commutation of the said sentence of death to that of impris- onment for life, and thereafter such proceedings were had and taken in said cause, that the said John R. Rogers, as governor of the State of Washington, dened the petition for a commutation of said sentence.
Sixteenth- That the said petitioner has no other remedy.

Seventeenth- That the said petitioner George Webster is now restrained of his liberty, by R. D. Speck, Sheriff of Spokane County State of Washington, at the Spokane County jail, in Spokane County, andhis said imprisonment and restraint is illegal in this;

(a) That the said information upon which the said petitioner was tried and convicted, and upon which judgment was rendered, does not state facts constituting a crime of an offense against the laws of the State of Washington, or of the United States.

(b) That the said petitioner is imprisoned andheld to answer for a capital and infamous crime without having been first indicted or presented by a Grand Jury as provided by Article 5 of the Amend- ments to the Constitution of the United States.

(c) That the said information did not inform the said petition- er of the nature and cause of the accusation against him as is re- quired by Article 6 of the Constitution of the United States, and as required by Sec. 22 of Art. 1 of the Constitution of the States of Washington.
(d) That the said information was filed against the said peti- tioner without any probable cause first having been established and shown.

(e) That the said petitioner did not have a speedy public trial by an impartial jury of the County, in which the offense is alleged to have been committed as guaranteed him, by Sec. 22 of Article 1 of t he Constitution of the State of Washington, and Article 5, 6, and 14 of the Amendments to the Constitution of the United States.

(f) That the said petitioner is deprived of his liberty and is about to be deprived of his life, without due process of law and in violation of Art. 5, 6, and 14 ofthe Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and in violation of Sec. 3, 21, and 22 of Art. 1 of the Constitution of the State of Washington.

(g) That sec. 25 of Art. 1 of the Constitution of the State of Washington, provides that "offenses heretofore required to be prose- cuted by indictent, may be prosecuted by information or by indict- ment, as shall be prescribed by law; is contrary to and in vio- lation of Articles 5 and 14 of the Amendments to the Constution of the United States, in that, the said section does not provide for a preliminary examinayion of th e accused and does not provide that probably cause shall first be established before the filing of an information against the accused, and in that, it deprives the accus- ed of the right of a preliminary examination of having probable cause of guilt first establlished before the filing of an information.

(h) That the said petitioner is illegally restrained of his liberty in that, the saud Sec. 25 of Art. 1 of the Constitution of the State of Washington and the laws of the State of Washington per- mitting and allowing persons accused of crime to be prosecuted by in formation are void, and in conflict with Article 5 and 14 of the Amendments to the Constitution of the United States.

(i) That the sai d Superior Court of the State of Washington, in and for the County of Spokane, who tried the said petitioner and rendered the said judgment, and sentence upon said information, had no jurisdiction yo try the said petitioner or render said judg- ment and sentence thereon.

(j) That the said information and all of the proceedings had an taken thereunder, and thereon, were and are absoluteu void and in violation of Sec. 3 Article 1 of the Constitution of the State of Washington, and in violation of Articles 5, 6, and 14 of the Amedments to the Constitution of the United States,

(k) That the said petitioner is not held in custody under and by virtue of any process issued on any final judgment of a court of competent jurisdiction, or for any contempt, of any court, officer or body having the authority in the premises to commit or upon a warrant issued from any Superior Court upon any indictment or upon aby valid or legal warrant issued from any Superior Court upon any valid information, but the said petitioner alleges, that each and all of the warrants and processes under which he is im- prisoned and detained, is and are, illegal and void in that, the judgment and sentence upon which these said warrants ar pretended warrants were issued, is void.

(l) That as shown by the petition for a writ of error Coram No- bis, one of tje jurors I. Lipschuetz, who tried the petitioner at the time of the said trial was a citizen and resident of the State of Idaho, and that said petitioner alleges, that he was not tried and convicted by a fair and impartial jury, or by a qualified and competent jury.

(m) That the said death warrant under which the said R. D. Speck as sheriff of Spokane County, Washington, intends to execute and hang your petitioner, is illegal and void in that, it does not contain the provisions required by the Laws of the State of Washing- ton, in that, it was issued after a laspe of more than ninety days from the date of judgment and sentence rendered, against pe- titioner and in that, no legal judgment was made or rendered upon which to predicate or cause the said warrant.

W H E R E F O R E your said petitioner prays that a writ of habeas corpus may be granted to him, direced to R. D. Speck, Sheriff of Spokane County, Washington, commanding him the said Sheriff to have and produce the body of the said petitioner before this Honorable Court, at a time and place in said writ to be speci- fied, to them and there receive what shall then and there be con- sidered by your Honor concerning the said petitioner, together with the time and cause of the detention of the said petitioner, and that the said Sheriff have then and there the said writ, and his return thereto, and that your said petitioner may be restored to his liberty and discharged from custody.
James E. Fenton Del Cary Smith and. James Hamilton Lewis Attorneys for petitioner.

I, George Webster being duly sworn say; that I am the petitioner above named. That I have read the foregoing pe- tition, know the contents thereof and the allegations therein are true as I verily believe.
Subscribed to and sworn to before me this 24th day of July, A.D.1899 Del Cary Smith N O T A R Y P U B L I C. For Washington, residing at Spokane, Washington.
United States of America State of Washington ss County of Spokane
